Hetherefore thought it advisable to ask a small conference ofmedical authorities how the question of attributability or-aggravation could be determined on more satisfactory lines.The conference was held on the 6th instant under the chairman-ship of Sir A. Griffith BosCawen, the Ministry, War Office,Admiralty, Insurance Commissioners, Local Government Board andCollege of Physicians being represented. In the course of thediscussion it was made clear that by the nature of the diseasethere were inevitably a variety of conditions present in militaryservice which might operate to aggravate, if not to set up,tuberculosis, including, in addition to actual exposure toinclement weather, the risk of infection in huts or barracks, andthe sudden change to out of door life: in the case of a manaccustomed to sedentary occupation. It was admitted that theState could not properly assume liability for cases in which aman had been suffering from phthisis on his entering into thearmy and had possibly spent all but a few days of his militaryservice in hospital in consequence of the disease. Theconclusion of the Committee was that,as in the French practice,the general presumption should be that the disease was in someway connected with the man's service unless evidence to thecontrary existed. The Committee adopted accordingly two principles, which which the Minister has accepted. (1,) That where the disease had developed during serviceover-seas the man should always be held to be pensionable. (2.) In any case where the man was passed! for militaryservice it should be presumed that the disease had beencontracted or aggravated by such service unless the invalid-ing board or the medical advisers of the Ministry aresatisfied that phthisis was present previous to enlistmentand that the disease was not aggravated by service.4L*.
